title: Policy-aware cross-city learning: A framework for sustainable urban development
authors: Ying Yang, Jiahao Zhan, Yang Liu, Xiaobo Qu
hypotheses: Cross-city learning can be enhanced through policy-aware computational frameworks that integrate policy contexts into machine learning for automated strategy adaptation
notes: Proposes computational translation of policy contexts into quantitative representations for direct integration into ML models, enabling automated cross-city policy adaptation
strengths: Novel integration of policy transfer theory with ML; addresses practical implementation challenges of cross-city learning
weaknesses: Limited empirical validation; focuses primarily on computational aspects rather than policy mechanisms
citation: Yang, Y., Zhan, J., Liu, Y., & Qu, X. (2025). Policy-aware cross-city learning: A framework for sustainable urban development. Nature Communications.

title: Experimentation or projectification of urban change? A critical appraisal and three steps forward
authors: Jonas Torrens, Timo von Wirth
hypotheses: Urban experimentation often suffers from projectification, treating experiments as isolated projects rather than systematic learning opportunities
notes: Critical analysis of urban experimentation trends, arguing for more systematic approaches to learning from experiments
strengths: Important critique of current experimental practices; provides clear recommendations for improvement
weaknesses: Primarily theoretical; limited empirical examples of successful systematic approaches
citation: Torrens, J., & von Wirth, T. (2021). Experimentation or projectification of urban change? A critical appraisal and three steps forward. Urban Transformations, 3, 8.

title: A Systematic Review of Urban Sustainability Assessment Literature
authors: Matthew Cohen
hypotheses: Urban sustainability assessment approaches lack standardization, limiting cross-city comparison and knowledge synthesis
notes: Comprehensive review of urban sustainability assessment methods, identifying gaps in comparative approaches
strengths: Systematic methodology; identifies key gaps in assessment frameworks
weaknesses: Limited focus on experimental interventions; primarily assessment-focused rather than causal
citation: Cohen, M. (2017). A systematic review of urban sustainability assessment literature. Sustainability, 9(11), 2048.

title: A survey of urban climate change experiments in 100 cities
authors: Vanesa Castán Broto, Harriet Bulkeley
hypotheses: Urban climate experiments follow systematic patterns across cities, but local adaptation creates significant variation in implementation
notes: Landmark study providing empirical analysis of urban climate experiments across 100 cities, revealing patterns and variations
strengths: Large-scale comparative analysis; systematic data collection; identifies patterns across diverse contexts
weaknesses: Limited causal analysis; focuses on experiment types rather than outcomes
citation: Castán Broto, V., & Bulkeley, H. (2013). A survey of urban climate change experiments in 100 cities. Global Environmental Change, 23(1), 92-102.

title: How Cities Learn: From Experimentation to Transformation
authors: James Evans, Tomáš Vácha, Henk Kok, Kelly Watson
hypotheses: Municipal learning from experimentation drives organizational change, but systematic approaches to capturing and applying learning are underdeveloped
notes: Focus on process learning and organizational change in municipalities conducting urban experiments
strengths: In-depth qualitative research with municipal practitioners; focus on learning mechanisms
weaknesses: Limited to European context; small sample size; primarily qualitative
citation: Evans, J., Vácha, T., Kok, H., & Watson, K. (2021). How cities learn: From experimentation to transformation. Urban Planning, 6(1), 3-13.

title: Evaluating the Cross-National Transferability of Policies: A Conceptual Framework
authors: Colin C. Williams, Rositsa Dzhekova
hypotheses: Cross-national policy transfer requires systematic evaluation frameworks to assess feasibility and transferability before implementation
notes: Provides practical framework for selecting and appraising policy measures for cross-national transfer
strengths: Practical framework; systematic approach to policy evaluation; emphasis on contextual fit
weaknesses: National rather than city focus; limited empirical validation of framework
citation: Williams, C. C., & Dzhekova, R. (2014). Evaluating the cross-national transferability of policies: A conceptual framework. Journal of Developmental Entrepreneurship, 19(04), 1450022.

title: Transfer of innovative policies between cities to promote sustainability: Case study evidence
authors: Greg Marsden, Karen T. Frick, Anthony D. May, Elizabeth Deakin
hypotheses: Policy transfer success depends on institutional capacity, political support, and technical feasibility rather than policy design alone
notes: Case study analysis of sustainability policy transfer between cities, identifying critical success factors
strengths: Detailed case studies; identifies practical factors influencing transfer success
weaknesses: Limited to transportation policies; small number of cases; limited quantitative analysis
citation: Marsden, G., Frick, K. T., May, A. D., & Deakin, E. (2011). Transfer of innovative policies between cities to promote sustainability: Case study evidence. Transportation Research Record, 2163(1), 89-96.

title: Towards a public policy of cities and human settlements in the 21st century
authors: Felix Creutzig, Sophia Becker, Peter Berrill, et al.
hypotheses: Cities require comprehensive public policy frameworks that integrate climate mitigation, adaptation, and well-being goals through place-specific approaches
notes: Proposes Goals-Intervention-Stakeholder-Enablers (GISE) framework for urban public policy that balances place-specificity with generalizable insights
strengths: Comprehensive framework; integration of multiple policy domains; practical applications
weaknesses: Primarily conceptual; limited empirical testing of framework across diverse cities
citation: Creutzig, F., Becker, S., Berrill, P., et al. (2024). Towards a public policy of cities and human settlements in the 21st century. npj Urban Sustainability, 4, 7.

title: An assessment framework for 15-minute Cities: Progress worldwide and implications for implementation
authors: Hui Wang, Ka Ho Tsoi, Becky P Y Loo
hypotheses: 15-minute city implementations vary significantly across contexts, requiring flexible assessment frameworks that can capture both universal principles and local adaptations
notes: Systematic review of 15-minute city implementations worldwide, developing assessment framework for policy evaluation
strengths: Global scope; systematic methodology; practical assessment tools
weaknesses: Limited to one policy concept; primarily descriptive rather than causal analysis
citation: Wang, H., Tsoi, K. H., & Loo, B. P. Y. (2025). An assessment framework for 15-minute Cities: Progress worldwide and implications for implementation. Transportation Research Part A, 183, 103997.

title: Perspectives on urban transformation research: transformations in, of, and by cities
authors: Katharina Hölscher, Niki Frantzeskaki
hypotheses: Urban transformations can be systematically categorized by their relationship to cities (in, of, by), enabling more precise comparative analysis
notes: Theoretical framework distinguishing types of urban transformation based on scale and agency
strengths: Clear theoretical framework; enables systematic comparison of transformation types
weaknesses: Primarily theoretical; limited empirical validation across diverse cases
citation: Hölscher, K., & Frantzeskaki, N. (2021). Perspectives on urban transformation research: transformations in, of, and by cities. Urban Transformations, 3, 2.

title: Transferring sustainable urban mobility policies: An institutional perspective
authors: Pınar Alpkokin
hypotheses: Institutional frameworks mediate the success of sustainable urban mobility policy transfer, requiring systematic analysis of institutional preconditions
notes: Institutional analysis of sustainable mobility policy transfer, emphasizing role of governance structures
strengths: Strong theoretical foundation; focus on institutional mechanisms; practical implications
weaknesses: Limited to mobility policies; primarily qualitative analysis; limited cross-city comparison
citation: Alpkokin, P. (2020). Transferring sustainable urban mobility policies: An institutional perspective. Transport Policy, 90, 1-12.

title: Urban Living Labs: how to enable inclusive transdisciplinary research?
authors: Pia Laborgne, Epongue Ekille, Jochen Wendel, et al.
hypotheses: Urban living labs require systematic approaches to inclusive transdisciplinary research, but current practices often exclude key stakeholders
notes: Analysis of urban living lab practices with focus on inclusion and transdisciplinary collaboration
strengths: Focus on inclusion and participation; practical recommendations; multi-city analysis
weaknesses: Limited to European context; primarily qualitative; limited outcome evaluation
citation: Laborgne, P., Ekille, E., Wendel, J., et al. (2021). Urban Living Labs: how to enable inclusive transdisciplinary research? Urban Transformations, 3, 20.

title: Experimental governance: the role of municipalities in urban living labs
authors: Annica Kronsell, Dalia Mukhtar-Landgren
hypotheses: Municipalities play critical but varied roles in urban living labs, affecting experimental outcomes and learning potential
notes: Analysis of municipal roles in urban living labs, examining how governance structures affect experimental processes
strengths: Clear focus on governance mechanisms; systematic comparison of municipal roles
weaknesses: Limited to Swedish context; small number of cases; limited outcome analysis
citation: Kronsell, A., & Mukhtar-Landgren, D. (2018). Experimental governance: the role of municipalities in urban living labs. European Planning Studies, 26(5), 988-1007.

title: Co-creation Pathways to Inform Shared Governance of Urban Living Labs in Practice: Lessons From Three European Projects
authors: Israa Hanafi Mahmoud, Eugenio Morello, David Ludlow, Giuseppe Salvia
hypotheses: Co-creation pathways in urban living labs require systematic governance frameworks to enable effective multi-stakeholder collaboration
notes: Analysis of co-creation processes in European urban living labs, developing governance frameworks
strengths: Practical governance frameworks; multi-project analysis; focus on implementation processes
weaknesses: Limited to European context; small sample size; limited quantitative analysis
citation: Mahmoud, I. H., Morello, E., Ludlow, D., & Salvia, G. (2021). Co-creation pathways to inform shared governance of urban living labs in practice: Lessons from three European projects. Frontiers in Sustainable Cities, 3, 690458.

title: Urban living laboratories: Conducting the experimental city?
authors: Harriet Bulkeley, Simon Marvin, Yuliya Voytenko Palgan, et al.
hypotheses: Urban living laboratories can be systematically categorized by their configuration, practice, and laboratory disposition, enabling comparative analysis
notes: Develops typology of urban living laboratories through comparative analysis of 40 European ULLs
strengths: Large-scale comparative analysis; systematic typology; strong theoretical framework
weaknesses: Limited to European context; primarily descriptive; limited outcome evaluation
citation: Bulkeley, H., Marvin, S., Palgan, Y. V., et al. (2019). Urban living laboratories: Conducting the experimental city? European Urban and Regional Studies, 26(4), 317-335.

title: Enhancing the contribution of urban living labs to sustainability transformations: a meta-lab approach
authors: Christian Scholl, Joop De Kraker, Marc van Dijk
hypotheses: Meta-lab approaches can enhance urban living lab contributions to transformation by facilitating systematic learning across distributed experiments
notes: Proposes meta-lab framework to connect learning processes across thematically related ULLs in different cities
strengths: Addresses key limitation of isolated ULL approaches; systematic framework for cross-city learning
weaknesses: Primarily conceptual; limited empirical testing; requires significant coordination infrastructure
citation: Scholl, C., De Kraker, J., & van Dijk, M. (2022). Enhancing the contribution of urban living labs to sustainability transformations: a meta-lab approach. Urban Transformations, 4, 7.

title: Toward Evidence-Based Urban Planning
authors: Ahmed El-Geneidy
journal: Journal of the American Planning Association
hypotheses: Urban planning can adopt evidence-based approaches from public health to improve policy evaluation and decision-making
notes: Proposes Risk of Bias Assessment and Evaluation of Certainty of Evidence tools for urban planning research
strengths: Systematic methodology adapted from proven field; practical tools for practitioners
weaknesses: Limited empirical testing in urban planning context; requires training for implementation
citation: El-Geneidy, A. (2022). Toward evidence-based urban planning. Journal of the American Planning Association, 88(3), 291-306.

title: INTERACT: A comprehensive approach to assess urban form interventions through natural experiments
authors: Yan Kestens, Meghan Winters, Daniel Fuller, et al.
hypotheses: Natural experiment approaches can provide causal evidence about urban form interventions' effects on health outcomes
notes: Methodological framework for evaluating urban interventions using natural experiments across four Canadian cities
strengths: Rigorous causal inference methods; multi-city design; longitudinal data collection
weaknesses: Limited to health outcomes; Canadian context; requires significant resources
citation: Kestens, Y., Winters, M., Fuller, D., et al. (2019). INTERACT: A comprehensive approach to assess urban form interventions through natural experiments. BMC Public Health, 19, 51.

title: Toward a Unifying Definition and Approach for Quantifying Urban Policy Performance
authors: Galen Newman, Chanam Lee, Shannon Van Zandt, Xinyue Ye, Dawn Jourdan
journal: Journal of Planning Education and Research
hypotheses: Standardized metrics for urban policy performance can be developed while maintaining sensitivity to local conditions
notes: Proposes framework for quantifying urban policy performance across diverse contexts
strengths: Addresses critical gap in policy evaluation; systematic framework development
weaknesses: Primarily conceptual; limited empirical testing across diverse policy domains
citation: Newman, G., Lee, C., Van Zandt, S., Ye, X., & Jourdan, D. (2023). Toward a unifying definition and approach for quantifying urban policy performance. Journal of Planning Education and Research, 42(4), 510-511.

title: Smart city construction and urban livability: evidence from a quasi-natural experiment in China
authors: Miao, Zhuang
hypotheses: Smart city construction significantly improves urban livability, with effects varying by city characteristics and implementation approaches
notes: Quasi-experimental analysis of smart city pilot program effects on urban livability across Chinese cities
strengths: Rigorous quasi-experimental design; large sample size; policy relevance
weaknesses: Limited to Chinese context; single policy intervention; limited mechanism analysis
citation: Miao, Z. (2025). Smart city construction and urban livability: evidence from a quasi-natural experiment in China. Humanities and Social Sciences Communications, 12, 123.

title: Study on Enhancement Effect of Climate-Resilient City Pilot Policy on Urban Ecological Resilience Based on Complex Adaptive System Theory
authors: Yuxin Yang, Lingyu Wang, Jia Chen, Dan Qiao
hypotheses: Climate-resilient city pilot policies significantly enhance urban ecological resilience, with effects moderated by government environmental attention
notes: Difference-in-differences analysis of climate-resilient city pilot program across 243 Chinese cities
strengths: Large-scale natural experiment; sophisticated analytical methods; policy-relevant findings
weaknesses: Limited to Chinese context; single policy domain; limited mechanism analysis
citation: Yang, Y., Wang, L., Chen, J., & Qiao, D. (2025). Study on enhancement effect of climate-resilient city pilot policy on urban ecological resilience. Land, 14(9), 1784.

title: Assessing the Impact of Climate-Resilient City Development on Urban Sustainability: Evidence from Chinese Pilot Cities
authors: Congwen Zhang
hypotheses: Climate-resilient city development significantly improves urban sustainability metrics across multiple dimensions
notes: Empirical analysis of climate-resilient city pilot program impacts on urban sustainability in China
strengths: Multi-dimensional sustainability analysis; policy relevance; systematic evaluation
weaknesses: Limited to Chinese context; single policy intervention; limited international comparison
citation: Zhang, C. (2025). Assessing the impact of climate-resilient city development on urban sustainability: Evidence from Chinese pilot cities. Sustainability, 17(10), 4381.

title: Comparative Urbanism: Tactics for Global Urban Studies
authors: Jennifer Robinson
hypotheses: Comparative urbanism requires decolonial approaches that avoid privileging certain cities as normative models
notes: Methodological framework for comparative urban studies that centers diverse urban experiences
strengths: Addresses bias in urban theory; systematic methodological approach; global perspective
weaknesses: Primarily theoretical; limited empirical applications; requires significant methodological expertise
citation: Robinson, J. (2022). Comparative Urbanism: Tactics for Global Urban Studies. Wiley Blackwell.

title: Governance for urban sustainability through real-world laboratories: Conditions for transformative capacity building
authors: C. Adler, et al.
hypotheses: Real-world laboratories can build transformative capacity for urban sustainability when governance conditions support transdisciplinary collaboration
notes: Analysis of governance conditions for successful real-world laboratories in urban sustainability
strengths: Focus on governance mechanisms; transformative capacity framework; practical implications
weaknesses: Limited empirical scope; primarily European context; limited outcome measurement
citation: Adler, C., et al. (2024). Governance for urban sustainability through real-world laboratories: Conditions for transformative capacity building. Cities, 152, 105158.
